article.value: Sections

When Proclamation No. 1081 was made effective on 21 Sep 1972, declaring martial law throughout the country, the film industry was not spared. The martial law regime brought massive changes in the landscape of Philippine cinema, both for the better and the worse. For the better, filmmakers were granted with seemingly unlimited support from the government through the cultural programs of the First Lady Imelda Marcos. For the worse, the deteriorating condition of Philippine society aggravated the plight of filmmakers from heavy taxation, increasing cost of production, and absurd censorship.

Martial law came with its own ideology of a new Philippine Republic. Indeed, barely a year after its declaration, the new 1973 Constitution was ratified by the Citizens Assembly. Under the banner of the New Society, the Marcoses envisioned a national identity that was modern yet traditionally rooted. Crime would be eradicated and discipline among the citizenry instilled. A curfew was imposed and those caught violating it would have to render community service. Stronger censorship was imposed on the broadcast media and film. This reimagined republic would be built in the framework of Imelda’s version of the Platonian “the true, the good, and the beautiful.” Part of the image formation was the prescribed haircut for boys, as sporting long hair was associated with the hippie movement and drug addiction, while girls kept their skirts at a certain length below the knee. To further this campaign, the presidential couple borrowed from folkloric characters to stand as metaphors for their leadership, such as the native Tagalog’s first man and woman, Malakas (Strong) and Maganda (Beautiful). Malakas was the virile and hardworking president, and Maganda was his beautiful partner. Meanwhile, protesters continued to rally against the regime’s consolidation of power, the increasing number of human rights violations, and the desaparecidos or those who had disappeared.
The Star System and the Dominant Genres

The fall of the studio system in the 1960s ushered in the rise of small-time studios that either continued to bank on the formulaic storylines and the same popular genres, without the control of long-term binding contracts and the quality control of the studios. The stars acquired an unprecedented power through their “star value” and “the hysterical fan had become a key player in the production and consumption of texts” (Reyes 2014, 14). Some of these stars established their own production companies. Some of the more successful ones were FPJ Productions of Fernando Poe Jr, RVQ Productions of Rodolfo V. Quizon or Dolphy, Imus Productions of Ramon Revilla, JE Productions and EMAR Pictures of Joseph Estrada, and D’Wonder Films of child star Niño Muhlach (del Mundo 2000, 105).

Big producers and studios of the 1950s and 1960s were long gone by the 1970s; new and rising production companies like Emperor, Agrix, and Regal Films of the second half of 1970s became dominant. During this period, however, no one company dominated the industry. But Regal Films, headed by Lily Monteverde, aka Mother Lily, would eventually become one of the major companies in the 1980s, along with Viva Films, under Vic del Rosario Jr, and Seiko Films, under Robbie Tan, which emerged in the late 1980s (del Mundo 2000, 115).

By this time, action, musicals, comedies, drama (or melodrama), and bomba dominated the genre movies, the cash cow of the industry. Producers often dictated the kinds of films to be made, hewing to formats that catered to popular taste. These films produced fantasies divorced from sociopolitical actualities and thus offered escapism and vehicles for didacticism.

Action films explored true crime, basing the storylines on the lives of infamous criminals. Nardong Putik, 1972, depicts the elusive gangster-cum-folk hero who relies on his amulet to survive gunfights, while Bitayin si… Baby Ama! (Execute… Baby Ama!), 1976, is about the executed murderer and gang leader Marciál “Baby” Ama. With the view that crime can be reflective of society, the bandit who comes from the lowest rung of the social ladder rises up to resist class oppression, the nemesis being the capitalist agent in cahoots with the state (Sidel 2000, 152). Some action films were comical and parodic of the secret-agent genre of the West. The dwarf Weng Weng rose to fame with For Your Height Only, 1981, which follows him as a secret agent fighting against crime, the title being a play on For Your Eyes Only, the James Bond film released that same year.

Comedy is best represented by Dolphy and NiñoMuhlach. The former was an established comedian who made his reputation playing an array of gay roles like Fefita Fofonggay viuda de Falayfay, 1973, and the latter a child actor who caught the fancy of audiences young and old by portraying a gallery of brattish but loveable kid, like in Ang Leon at ang Daga (The Lion and the Mouse), 1975, where Muhlach appears with Fernando Poe Jr. Capitalizing on Dolphy’s hilarious characterization of gays and Niño’s endearing portraits of smart-alecky little boys, Lino Brocka brought together the two comedy stars in Ang Tatay Kong Nanay (My Father the Mother), 1978, which tells the story of an unwanted child whom a gay beautician takes under his wing and of the difficulties that the beautician experiences for taking on the double task of father and mother.

The musical was another popular genre. The Nora Aunor–Tirso Cruz III love team who started as singers became known with Guy and Pip, 1971. Another musical, My Blue Hawaii, 1972, is a box-office hit that meanders with its storyline and does very little with production value, drawing viewers instead through the popularity of the Nora-Tirso love team. Another tandem that offered competition to Guy and Pip was the team of Vi and Bot or Vilma Santos and Edgar Mortiz.

The melodrama catered to the female moviegoers with films featuring female characters dealing with personal issues, such as a tragic love affair. Danny Zialcita depicted the extravagance of the ruling class, using “sosyal realism” (“sosyal” is slang for anything fancy), which strikes the irony of glamor amid abject poverty (Dimla 2014). In Gaano Kadalas ang Minsan? (How Often Is Once?), 1982, the husband Louie pretends to be the father of Lily’s dying child at his own wife Elsa’s request. Among the three, Elsa dominates because she is in the position of privilege. T-Bird at Ako (Lesbian Love), 1982, takes advantage of the popularity of Vilma Santos and Nora Aunor by putting them together in one film about tomboy lawyer Sylvia (played by Aunor) who offers to stand as legal counsel pro bono to nightclub dancer Isabel (Santos). Their nascent affair gets disrupted in the intrusion of Isabel’s male lover Dante (Dindo Fernando), thus moving Sylvia from her position of power. These two films end with the assertion that power resides in the institution and that whatever privilege they have remains valid only when it stays under the control of the institution (Dimla 2014, 67).

The other form of melodrama, targeting the male audience, was the bomba. Bomba helped regenerate the economically moribund Philippine cinema after studios had closed down and fewer producers took risks investing in big productions. From 1970 to 1972, the genre followed the worldwide trend of sexual revolution, and the films were able to go through the censors. But the martial law regime took a firmer stand in clamping down on such films, prompting those in the industry to create the bold film or “wet look” (1974-76), which teases with shots of the drenched actresses and sometimes renders unrealistically scenes of women taking a bath in a chemise (Tolentino 2010, 102-3). An example is Celso Ad. Castillo’s Ang Pinakamagandang Hayop sa Balat ng Lupa (The Most Beautiful Animal on the Face of the Earth), 1974, starring Gloria Diaz, the 1969 Miss Universe. The second wave of bold films from 1976 to 1982 grew more daring as underage actresses were cast in movies like Katorse (Fourteen) and Problem Child, 1980. At that time, the minimum voter’s age had been reduced to the world’s lowest at 14 (Tolentino 2010, 104). Despite the censors, low-budget genre movies, which production companies exploited and profited from, received approval provided that they were appended with an epilogue explaining that the problems of immorality and violence depicted in them had been resolved in the New Society.

Prior to the 1970s, the Cebuano film industry had a verdant history that existed in the periphery of, if not parallel with, the Tagalog movies. By the 1970s, the Cebuano movie industry was already in decline and had reduced its production of films, but it was still an optimistic period. A number of films were produced in the early 1970s, including Medalyon nga Bulawan (Gold Medallion), produced by Annabelle Rama, Mayor Andal, Batul sa Mactan (Battle of Mactan), Anino sa Villa Lagrimas (Shadow at Villa Lagrimas), Bulawan sa Lapok (Gold in the Mud), Antonio Solitaryo, and Mga Milagro sa Santo Niño (Miracles of Sto. Niño). Other films include Aliyana and Ikaduhang Bathala (Second God), 1974 (Noriega et al. 1995). Gimingaw Ako (I Long for You), 1974, shot entirely in Cebu City and produced by Gloria Sevilla and Amado Cortez, won the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Best Actress award for Gloria Sevilla and Best Supporting Actress award for her daughter Suzette Ranillo.

During its decline, many stars of the Cebuano cinema transferred to Manila and made Tagalog films. Some of the producers and filmmakers also did television programs. Ultimately, the Cebuano film industry became dormant. The last of its films are Ang Manok ni San Pedro (Saint Peter’s Rooster), 1975, and Itlog Manoy Orange (The Orange Egg Vendor), 1976. The regional industry had to fold up because it could not compete with the larger industry based in Manila, whose language was Filipino (del Mundo 2000, 100).
New Cinema

The nationalist movement in the 1960s that generated an interest in mass culture influenced Filipino film, and this became apparent later in the works of the younger directors (Lumbera 1983, 23). Informed as well by the French New Wave (Nouvelle Vague), Italian Neorealism, and art cinema from Sweden, Germany, Italy, Japan, and India, this generation of filmmakers of the 1970s would redefine Philippine cinema (del Mundo 2000, 105). Spanning the entire duration of the martial law, this era of filmmaking not only elevated the art but also served as a vehicle to speak against the dictatorship.

Lino Brocka, the leading figure of this New Cinema, started as an apprentice to director Eddie Romero in a number of American movies and then directed movies for Lea Productions before founding his own company, CineManila. Its first film, Tinimbang Ka Ngunit Kulang (Weighed But Found Wanting), 1974, proved that an artistic film could also be a commercial success. Involved in the protest movements, Brocka would also make films critical of the regime. Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag (Manila: In the Claws of Light), 1975, introduces the possibility of mass action yielding individual and social transformation. In the film, Julio Madiaga leaves their fishing village for Manila to look for his girlfriend, Ligaya Paraiso, who was forced into prostitution in the city. Replete with stark imagery of poverty in the face of urban progress, the film includes scenes of street protests during a time when it was prohibited (Tolentino 2012, 121-24). Insiang, 1976, about a young woman who gets enmeshed in the life of her mother and her mother’s lover, reintroduced Philippine cinema to international audiences through its participation in the Cannes Film Festival.

Ishmael Bernal would also make a name for himself as a filmmaker. According to Lumbera, while Brocka explores social realism, Bernal transforms film into a philosophical rumination. Nunal sa Tubig (Speck in the Water), 1976, unfolds the story of a fishing village that is being destroyed by environmental pollution before the persistent gaze of the camera (Lumbera 1983, 44). The slow progress of the narrative is a sharp contrast to the development that the New Society boasts of (Santiago 2012). Manila by Night, 1980, meanwhile, assembles characters who contradict the image of the City of Man, Imelda’s purportedly genteel capital. The Interim Board of Censors for Motion Pictures banned this film, despite representations with Imelda Marcos that the appended voice-over in the epilogue clarifies that each of the characters had eventually reformed. This led Moritz de Hadeln, director-general of Berlin International Film Festival, to criticize the regime’s hypocrisy in its so-called benevolent authoritarianism. The film was later approved for local release, but with the issuance of a four-page list of cuts and changes, including the change of the title into City after Dark. Relasyon (An Affair), 1982, about a woman who walks away from a relationship, turns on its head the heteronormative perpetuation of the macho man and the dedicated wife, as embodied by the First Couple.

Other films followed along the line of realism: Behn Cervantes’s Sakada (Seasonal Cane Workers), 1976, faithfully reflects Philippine society that is in a state of unrest against the old order. In its three interrelated stories of an hacendero family, the family of sakada or migrant workers, and the formation of a labor union, the film conveys the need for solidarity of freedoms (Lumbera 1983, 43-44). Lupita Concio’s Minsa’y Isang Gamu-gamo (Once a Moth), 1976, concerns a Filipino nurse who is about to leave for the United States when an American GI shoots down his brother. Written by Marina Feleo-Gonzales, the film criticizes the presence of US military bases in the Philippines (Tiongson 1976). Marcos, incidentally, had also received constant flak for being America’s lapdog (Campos 2007, 38).

Other filmmakers who broke into the industry during this period include Mike de Leon, who decided to direct his own film with the mysterious and brooding Itim (Rites of May), 1976, followed by Kung Mangarap Ka’t Magising (When You Dream and Wake Up), 1977, his tribute to the romance-musicals of LVN. Other filmmakers made Philippine cinema lively, like Celso Ad. Castillo, Nympha, 1971; Maryo J. de los Reyes, High School circa ’65, 1979; Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Tanikala (Chain), 1980; Laurice Guillen, Kasal? (Marriage?), 1980; and Mel Chionglo, Playgirl, 1981.

Some directors made outstanding period films. Eddie Romero’s Ganito Kami Noon … Paano Kayo Ngayon? (This Was How We Were… What Happens to You Now?), 1976, follows Kulas in his quest for the Filipino identity during the 1896 Philippine Revolution and the Philippine-American War. The journey in which he encounters racial and ideological diversity “is a reminder of identity ultimately being about community” (Santiago 2012). Mario O’Hara’s Tatlong Taong Walang Diyos (Three Godless Years), 1976, is set during the Japanese Occupation, and Peque Gallaga’s Oro, Plata, Mata (Gold, Silver, Death), 1982, also set during World War II, illustrates how Filipinos can turn against one another in time of war.

The films of Joey Gosiengfiao and Elwood Perez are also the antitheses to those of Brocka and Bernal, depicting a highly aestheticized cinematic world with their female characters who refuse to be victims. The campy Temptation Island, 1980, for example, parodies the Filipino’s fascination with beauty pageants (Zafra 2005, 214).

Cinematography was another aspect that was given importance during this period. Most of the cinematographers who emerged in the 1970s and 1980s worked with the great directors of the time. Eventually, some became directors themselves. The most famous among these cinematographers is Mike de Leon who did the cinematography for Maynila: Sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag and Aguila, 1980. Another important cinematographer of the time is Rody Lacap who photographed Kisapmata (Blink of an Eye), 1981, Batch ’81, 1982, and Oro, Plata, Mata, Misteryo sa Tuwa (Joyful Mystery), and Sister Stella L., 1984. Conrado Baltazar did his important films with Lino Brocka, like Insiang and Jaguar (Guard), 1979.

New screenwriters broke into the industry during this period, including Mario O’Hara, Orlando Nadres, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Marina Feleo-Gonzales, Jose Lacaba, Ricardo Lee, and Mauro Gia Samonte. Similarly, also given importance were production designers like Mel Chionglo, Cesar Hernando, Fiel Zabat, Laida Lim Perez; editors like Ike Jarlego Jr and Jess Navarro; sound engineers like Amang Sanchez and Ramon Reyes; and musical scorers like Max Jocson, Lutgardo Labad, and Ryan Cayabyab. Other than the stars and directors, these important players were given due credit.
Alternative Cinema

The rebirth of the Philippine short film happened mostly in the academe, through film courses in universities and support from private groups like the Mowelfund Film Institute. This received a further boost when the Manila Short Film Festival was organized in April 1981 at the University of the Philippines (UP) to encourage the development of short films in the time of government-controlled mass media. The Experimental Cinema of the Philippines, the government agency created to foster the development of cinema, also organized its own short film festival to promote awareness of the form.

Examples of films that deal with the private visions of their filmmakers are Orfeo Marino, a collaboration between poet and dramatist Virginia Moreno and photographer Romy Vitug; and Mount Banahaw, Holy Mountain, 1976, Amable “Tikoy” Aguiluz VI’s documentation of Rizal cultists in Mount Banahaw, which won the Silver Prize, professional category, in the 1976 Youth Filmmakers of Asia Film Festival in Shiraz, Iran. Probably the most celebrated is Kidlat Tahimik’s Mababangong Bangungot (Perfumed Nightmare), 1977, which won the International Federation of Film Critics award at the Berlin Film Festival.

Although animation had already taken a serious turn in 1953, with the pioneering 8mm film by komiks cartoonist Larry Alcala, it barely gained traction for lack of funding. However, outsourced projects regenerated interest in animation. Foreign production companies, like Hanna Barbera and Toei, outsourced some projects in the country. The Marcos regime systematized outsourcing projects and labor export, as well, to improve dollar remittances to the country (Tolentino 2001). During the sixth anniversary of martial law, the state commissioned cartoonist Nonoy Marcelo to make the full-length animated feature Tadhana (Destiny), 1978, produced by Imee Marcos, the first of a series that would popularize Marcos’s rewriting of history (Vera 2009). Supposed to be replayed and released in commercial theaters, Tadhana premiered on 21 Sep 1978 but was never broadcast or screened commercially again.
Censorship Under Martial Law

In 1972, the governing body that implemented the guidelines for film was the Board of Censors for Motion Pictures (BCMP), created under Republic Act 3060 of 1961 (approved on 17 Jun 1961). Pursuant to Proclamation 1081, President Marcos issued Letter of Instruction 13 on 29 Sep 1972, which extended the powers of the BCMP by banning films with undesirable content from public exhibition “in order to safeguard the morality of our society, particularly the youth, against the negative influence of certain motion pictures.” Ironically, Marcos himself was a victim of censorship when his biopic Iginuhit ng Tadhana: The Ferdinand E. Marcos Story (Destined by Fate) was banned from screening. This incident happened during the Macapagal-Marcos presidential elections in 1965. Hernando writes: “More than any government official here, therefore, President Marcos deeply understands what it must be like to have one’s story censored; he once had a firsthand experience of it as a victim” (2001).

Marcos used censorship as one of the tools to expurgate undesirable images that would hinder his revisionist programs of Philippine history for his Bagong Lipunan (New Society). Through Executive Order 585 (22 Mar 1980), 745 (13 Nov 1981), and 757 (29 Dec 1981), the BCMP was reconstituted to extend its powers to broadcast television and renamed Board of Review for Motion Pictures and Television (BRMPT). Furthermore, Marcos also attempted to extend the jurisdiction of the BRMPT “to include, among others, live entertainment [live performances such as theatrical presentations], video tapes and similar media” through Executive Order 868 (1 Feb 1983) and 876 (18 Feb 1983), for the reason that previous provisions under BRMPT “could not adequately cope with the problems generated by technological advances in motion pictures, television, video tapes and similar media.”

Under the chairmanship of Guillermo de Vega, producers were made to submit finished scripts to the BCMP before they could begin to shoot a movie. This directive was based on the new set of Guidelines on Film Production and Exhibition, stipulating “Submission to the Board of three (3) bound copies of the film script including a synopsis, sequence treatment, names of the actors and actresses in the cast and the director.” Although improvisation was the notorious tradition in the industry during this period, the producers dutifully complied with the regulation. Producers hired journalists, writers, novelists, poets, and columnists in order to improve their chances of getting their scripts approved. The guidelines, however, also facilitated the butchering of a good screenplay as the board dissected scenes and would not consider their relation to the whole artistic intent of the project. Despite the scrutiny of censors, lewd films, like Mga Uhaw na Bulaklak, Part II (Thirsty Flowers), 1975, were still produced, prompting newspaper columnist Teodoro Valencia to move for the investigation of the board (del Mundo 1983, 81-82).

These changes in the already oppressive provisions during the later years of the Marcos regime were tested, protested, and challenged. With the Concerned Artists of the Philippines, Brocka questioned these rules under BRMPT as “double standard” in being tolerant to foreign films against local films; “ambiguous” with rules like “allowing the exposure of one breast” of a female but not two breasts; and “arbitrary” in being unpredictable with the decisions (Tiongson 2013, 73). Thus, films like Ang Babae sa Ulog (The Woman in the Sleeping Quarters), 1981, by Eduardo Palmos and Hubad na Gubat (Naked Jungle), 1982, by Lito Tiongson were allowed public exhibition despite depicting “open sexual practices and female breast exposure” because they were “part of tribal customs and costumes” (David 2010, 67-68).

BRMPT was further tested by the landmark case of Gonzalez vs Katigbak. In 1984, the BRMPT under Maria Kalaw Katigbak attempted to ban the exhibition of Brocka’s Bayan Ko : Kapit sa Patalim (My Country: Gripping the Knife’s Edge). Katigbak’s censorship rulings met protests from filmmakers and artists (Tiongson 2001b, xx). On 22 Jul 1985, the Supreme Court, citing the constitutional right to freedom of expression, ruled that the power of the board was limited to the classification of films and that it did not have the power to restrict the exhibition of films.

A few months later, Presidential Decree 1986, issued on 5 Oct 1985, abolished the BRMPT, reorganized Executive Order 876-A, and created the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB). The MTRCB, despite its name “Review and Classification Board,” still had censorship power even though it admitted members from the industry into the board as preparation for eventual self-regulation.
Film Organizations

The Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), through Executive Order 640-A, was established in 1981. The FAP was composed of the Philippine Motion Picture Directors Association; Screenwriters Guild of the Philippines; Katipunan ng mga Artistang Pilipino sa Pelikula at Telebisyon; Production Designers Guild of the Philippines; Filipino Society of Cinematographers; Pilipino Musical Directors Association Inc; Motion Picture Audio Society of the Philippines; United Film Editors Guild for Motion Picture; Assistant Directors, Production Managers Association for Motion Pictures Inc; Independent Movie Producers and Distributors Association of the Philippines; Philippine Motion Picture Producers Association Inc; and Movie Workers Welfare Foundation Inc (FAP 2015).

On 29 Jan 1982, the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines (ECP) was created under Executive Order 770. It was “formed under the sponsorship of First Lady Imelda Marcos, the self-appointed art patron of the country” (del Mundo 2000, 111). ECP was also created “to ease the tension created by artists who have banded together to form Free the Artist Movement and the Concerned Artists of the Philippines” (Cruz 2007). The martial law government of Marcos set up the ECP to encourage the film industry to lend support to the fascist regime. ECP, under its offices, was tasked to manage and operate the Manila Film Center (MFC) and the Film Fund (Tiongson 2001b, xxiii); administer a film ratings and classification system under the Film Ratings Board, which also granted tax incentives to films deemed of high quality (del Mundo 2000, 112); hold annual scriptwriting contest, and produce and fund the winning works through its Alternative Cinema Department; establish and operate the National Film Archive; and hold the Manila International Film Festival (Tiongson 2001b, xxiii).

ECP was able to produce five films: Himala (Miracle), 1982, written by Ricardo Lee and directed by Ishmael Bernal; Oro, Plata, Mata, written by Jose Javier Reyes and directed by Peque Gallaga; Soltero (Single), 1984, written by Bienvenido Noriega Jr and directed by Pio de Castro III; Misteryo sa Tuwa, written and directed by Abbo de la Cruz and co-produced with Viva Films; and Isla (Island), 1985, written by Celso Ad. Castillo with screenplay by Jose Javier Reyes and directed by Celso Ad. Castillo.

The Manila International Film Festival was Imelda’s attempt to “transplant Cannes from Manila, a feat that lasted for two festivals” (del Mundo 2000) in the years 1982 and 1983, with a dry run in 1981 (Tiongson 2001b, xxiii). The Manila Film Center, built on reclaimed land, was designed to look like the Parthenon and required thousands of laborers working in three shifts round-the-clock. On 17 Nov 1981, the upper scaffolding collapsed and buried workers in wet cement, some impaled with steel bars. A nine-hour news media blackout was ordered until the government released an official statement. The construction continued and the building was finished in time for the festival’s opening night on 18 Jan 1982.

Since Maria Kalaw Katigbak took over the job of BRMPT chair in 1984, resistance to the dictatorship was growing in militancy. Various artists from different fields, especially the filmmakers, staged rallies against her censorship rules. The Free-the-Artist, Free-the-Media rallies eventually formed the Free-the-Artist Movement (FTA) with LinoBrocka and BehnCervantes at the helm. They challenged Katigbak’s board over decisions seen as contrary to the rights of film artists. They held a rally at Liwasang Bonifacio on 11 Feb 1983. A precursor to the 1983 FTA was a 1978 rally in support of legislative bills against censorship (Hernando 2001, 8-9). It was during this period that the problems encountered by filmmakers over the exhibition abroad of certain films like Insiang, Manila by Night/City after Dark, and Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim, exposed the arbitrariness and devious logic of the board as a control body for the dictatorial regime of Ferdinand Marcos. FTA would eventually evolve into the Concerned Artists of the Philippines.

Marcos reduced the funding for ECP from 17 million pesos in 1983 to 5 million pesos in 1984 (Tiongson 2001, xxv). This led ECP to look for other means of sustaining its programs by showing sexually explicit films at the Manila Film Center. Films shown at the MFC were exempted from censorship and attracted a large viewership. Through clamors and protests, Executive Order 1051 in 1985 turned ECP into a private foundation, which was eventually abolished in 1986.
Film in the Academe

Film in the academe swelled in the 1970s as the way of experiencing film became more academic, theoretical, and scholarly. More filmmakers were learning the craft from formal education instead of learning on the set. By the 1980s, professionals and institutions, both academic and non-academic, provided film training to young film artists, technicians, and managers (Diaz 1990, 2-5; Tiongson 2010, 28).

The first institution to provide a film program was the Department of Cinema and Television of Pamantasan ng Lungsod ng Maynila in 1970, initiated by Ben Pinga (Tiongson 2010, 28-29). This was followed in 1972 by the creation of a film animation course by the cartoonist Larry Alcala at the College of Fine Arts of the University of the Philippines Diliman. In 1974, De La Salle University and Ateneo de Manila University started offering film courses in their Communication programs. In 1976, the University of the Philippines Film Center was established. By 1981, UP was the first institution to offer a full undergraduate program in film through the Film and Audiovisual Communication Department of the College of Mass Communication, which offered a Bachelor of Arts in Film. It has been turning out potential filmmakers and film scholars to carry on the work that the artists in the industry and the researchers in the academe have started.

Other colleges, universities, organizations, and institutions followed soon, like the Mowelfund Film Institute, offering filmmaking workshops. Film showings, lectures, and workshops were also held “in embassies and foreign cultural centers,” like the Thomas Jefferson Cultural Center, the Goethe Institut, and the Alliance Française (del Mundo 2000).

The various schools offering film courses through their Communication programs add every year to the pool of youths interested in a career in filmmaking. These young would-be filmmakers kept filmmaking alive outside the mainstream of the industry. In the succeeding decades, the products of these schools would figure prominently as directors, writers, cinematographers, or editors of the new wave of Philippine Independent Cinema in the 2000s.
1983-86: Aquino’s Assassination and the 1986 EDSA Revolt

Martial law was officially lifted on 17 Jan 1981, a month before the papal visit of John Paul II in the country (Santos 2015), but Marcos retained all his legislative powers, including the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus. But the assassination of opposition leader Benigno “Ninoy” Aquino Jr on 21 Aug 1983 fueled the increasing protests against the fascist regime and fomented the fence-sitting elite to finally get actively involved.

After the assassination, there was a noticeable decline of output in the 1980s, attributed to the worsening economy and the deteriorating political and economic conditions. But the industry continued to churn out genre movies. Action biopics of criminals continued in Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s Alyas Baby Tsina (Alias Baby Tsina), 1984. Comedies thrived in the 1980s, with leading comedians like Dolphy, Chiquito, Roderick Paulate, and the trio Tito, Vic, and Joey, making box-office hits (Tiongson 2001b, xviii). Fantasy also provided an escape, like Inday Bote (Inday the Bottle Trader), 1985.

Danny Zialcita continued examining the bourgeoisie vis-à-vis widespread poverty in films like Lalakwe, 1985, which offers a glimpse of poverty through a painting that depicts the demolition of a shanty (Dimla 2014, 72). Bomba films from 1983 to 1986, however, took on the forms of FF (fighting fish) or pornographic films and penekula (portmanteau of “penetration” and “pelikula,” which means cinema), with some getting screening time at the Manila Film Center when the Experimental Cinema of the Philippines needed to raise funds for its own maintenance (Tolentino 2010, 105). Sexy stars were underage and exploitatively introduced to the public with catchy names, like the “soft drink beauties” of talent manager Dr Rey dela Cruz, including Pepsi Paloma, Sarsi Emmanuelle, and Coca Nicolas.

But even then, there were attempts to go against the mainstream and tackle realities of the time. Scorpio Nights, 1985, by PequeGallaga takes the structure of the hard-core porn and casts in it the story of an idle young wife. Her husband, a security guard, works the night shift. A voyeur student boarder who lives on the upper floor is drawn into a lurid affair with the young wife that proves fatal in the end. First-rate production values gave the film the commercial gloss of the mainstream that the usual low-budget bomba film lacked. This was perhaps indicative of a serious effort to explore the boundaries between art and pornography. Historically contextualizing the film, it can be an allegory for inner decay, represented in the tenements, set against the backdrop of the New Order, which happens outside but suggested within the filmic range (Espiritu 2007, 498).

Tikoy Aguiluz’s Boatman, 1984, is another attempt to refurbish the bomba as a vehicle for serious filmic expression. Aguiluz follows the moral decay of a provinciano (country boy) boatman from Pagsanjan. He gives up the rural life and the hand-to-mouth existence there for life in the big city. In Manila, the grinding poverty leads him to accept work as a partner to a young woman who performs in a live sex show. In time, he is reduced to a sex instrument and is eventually destroyed by the moneyed and the powerful. It is Boatman’s socioeconomic perspective, perfunctory though it might be, that somewhat redeems its exploitative intentions.

The deterioration in the industry and the conditions of martial law did not deter some filmmakers from making socially and politically relevant films. Mike de Leon’s Kisapmata is a psychological drama about an incestuous father who controls the married life of his daughter and son-in-law and “has been read as an allegory of the dictatorial regime, the house the nation, and the patriarch Marcos” (Espiritu 2007, 48). Batch ’81, a harrowing account of eager college freshmen initiating themselves in a fraternity hazing, can be read within the nationalist discourse as a microcosm of “the characteristic violence that attends fascism, blind obedience, and irrational conformity” (ibid.).

By then other commercial giants bankrolled controversially political films. Sister Stella L. was produced by Regal Films and starred Vilma Santos. Didactic, it hews close to the conventions of a political film with the sociopolitical tropes of abuse and the awakening to activism. In spite of its overtly anti-regime tone, the film was classified for General Patronage and approved for release without cuts.

Other films with a strong political stance, however, would still undergo prohibitions from the censors. Bayan Ko: Kapit sa Patalim , about the dire consequence a man has to suffer under a big systematized oppressive system, even had to be smuggled out for the Cannes Film Festival in France. On 6 Nov 1985, however, three days after the announcement of the snap elections, the film was released in theaters.

The assassination of Sen Benigno Aquino Jr and the subsequent aggressive mass movement in reaction to it spurred Nick Deocampo, under the pseudonym Rosa ng Maynila, to make an equally revolutionary film. After the documentary Oliver, 1983, which pits the transvestite character against the machismo of a militarized society, Deocampo did Children of the Regime, 1985, which links child prostitution to the military. The third, Revolutions Happen Like Refrains in a Song, 1987, explores the joy and dismay with the succeeding government. Lav Diaz made Banlaw (Cleansing), 1986, a three-minute film of a man who hangs himself after watching a monk self-immolate on television. Diaz (2007, 64) affirms its subtle protest against martial law. Roxlee’s short film, Juan Gapang (Johnny Crawl), 1986, is about a ghostly white man who crawls from the bustling EDSA to the infamous Manila Film Center in search of his destiny. More explicit political films were made by nongovernment activist groups, like AsiaVisions’ Arrogance of Power, 1982, and AlterHorizons’ Edjop, 1986.

To show his presidential legitimacy, that the people still wanted him in power, Marcos declared a snap election to be held on 7 Feb 1986. Running against him was the widow of the assassinated senator, Corazon C. Aquino. Within the 45-day campaign period, the state-controlled media, like Radio Philippines Network and Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation, refused to give the opposition airtime. On the eve of the election, a full-page manifesto by the so-called group Coalition of Writers and Artists for Freedom and Democracy urged voters to choose the status quo “to preserve what has already been achieved in terms of cultural advancement and to proceed further under an enlightened and transformed national leadership equipped to face the pressures of change and advance our national and spiritual progress.” Among the signatories were prominent directors, writers, and actors.

Marcos supposedly won the elections but the rampant electoral frauds drove the people to take to the street in what would go down in world history as a nonviolent protest for democracy. The 1986 EDSA Revolt marked the end of a nearly 20-year-long period of fascism. After the rush of winning democracy back, the Marcos’s excesses would weigh in on the succeeding years with the country’s economy in ruins, from which the film industry had to pick itself up.  Written by Bienvenido Lumbera, updated by Jeffrey Javier and Julian de la Cerna

text:
Even though the 1986 EDSA Revolt successfully deposed Ferdinand Marcos and ushered a sense of restoration and hope across the nation, Philippine cinema entered a dark period in the years that followed, characterized by the continuing ordeals with taxation, rising production costs, competition with foreign films, censorship, piracy, and commercialism among movie producers and theater owners (Tiongson 2010). Several coup d’etat attempts staged by political rivals and members of the armed forces besieged Corazon Aquino’s government. Political instability in the late 1980s weakened the already feeble economy after the Marcos dictatorship. As a result, film revenues declined (Tiongson 2001). Moreover, the 1990 earthquake, the 1992 eruption of Mount Pinatubo, and the flood in Ormoc, Leyte, obliterated many movie houses all over the country (Lumbera 1994).

 

New media conglomerates Star Cinema and GMA Films, as well as OctoArts Films, Viva Films, Regal Films, and Unitel Pictures, somehow sustained the industry in the 1990s. Though a new production outfit borne from media giant ABS-CBN, Star Cinema joined Viva and Regal as the top producers of the 1990s but would surpass both companies in the 2000s. Several new producers also made low-budget commercial films that rode on trends such as sex comedies and soft-core porn (Tiongson 2010).

 

 

President Fidel V. Ramos declared 1994 “The Year of the Filipino Cinema,” challenging the industry to produce superior films. However, film critics noted the dearth of quality films during the period. The industry was in such poor shape that in 1994 not one of the six entries in the Metro Manila Film Festival (MMFF) won the Best Screenplay, Best Director, and Best Picture awards (Mediawatch 1995). Mindless entertainment soon became the MMFF’s trademark. The festival that bore some of the finest films in the history of Philippine cinema was yielding mostly mediocre movies year after year.

 

The decade saw the commemoration of the 75th year of Dalagang Bukid (Country Maiden), the World Cinema Centennial celebration, the centenaries of the Philippine revolution and independence, and the rise of Joseph Ejercito Estrada, an actor, to the presidency. The Movie and Television Review and Classification Board, headed by Estrada’s appointee Armida Siguion-Reyna, installed members from the film industry and reformed the way it evaluated films. In 2000, after a former ally disclosed that he had received millions of payoff from illegal gambling, Joseph Estrada was tried by an impeachment court and, in 2001, was ousted from the presidency. Estrada’s removal became the backdrop of Joel Lamangan’s Hubog (Wretched Lives), 2001.

 

The period was also marred by high-profile arrests of movie stars involved in illegal drugs and firearms possession, and scandals such as the one in which a talent manager manipulated the awarding ceremonies during the now-defunct Manila Film Festival in favor of her clients, both of whom were wrongfully announced as winners in the lead acting categories. These incidents further tarnished the viewing public’s faith in local films (Tiongson 2010, 26). Moreover, a fiscal crisis hit Southeast Asian economies in the late 1990s, devaluing the peso and stalling the Philippine economy, which was poised to recover during the Ramos administration.

 

 

Filipino films were rapidly losing audiences to Hollywood spectacles, whose distribution was bolstered by the government’s endorsement of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, ironically in spite of the state’s attempts to support the industry. Moreover, European and Asian art films, made available through special screenings, cable television, and video rental companies, influenced viewers who began to tire of the formulas and poor production values of Filipino movies (Tiongson 2010, 4-6).

 

The deaths of Lino Brocka in 1991 and Ishmael Bernal in 1996 marked the end of the extraordinary period that began in the 1970s. Mike de Leon directed only two movies after 1985: Aliwan Paradise (Entertainment Paradise), which is part of Southern Winds, an anthology of Asian films launched in 1992; and Bayani ng 3rd World (Third World Hero) in 1999. Eddie Romero and Celso Ad. Castillo directed a few more movies in the 1990s and the 2000s, but none of these films approached the quality of their early work.

 

Filmmaking in the country can be categorized into three areas: the “center of mainstream,” which treats movies simply as commodity; the “periphery of mainstream,” which aims to bring the audience more than just entertainment; and the space for independent filmmaking, which considers film an art form (del Mundo 2013, 49). In 2001, films such as Ano Bang Meron Ka? (What Is It That You Have?), Dudurugin Ko Pati ang Buto Mo (I Will Crush Even Your Bones), and Balahibong Pusa (Cat’s Fur) typified the mainstream. The periphery of the mainstream produced Mark Meily’s Crying Ladies, 2003, a comedy about women who cry at funerals for a fee, and Yam Laranas’s Radyo (Radio), 2001, a visually playful suspense thriller about a female radio disc jockey stalked by a crazed listener. Farther away from the mainstream are the independent films.

 

Philippine independent filmmaking made a leap into the world stage when Raymond Red’s Anino (Shadow), 2000, a 13-minute film about a day in the life of an amateur photographer, won the Palme d’Or for short film at the Cannes Film Festival. Raymond Red’s win, along with the earlier digital releases in film festivals, such as the CCP Independent Film and Video Competition, heralded the revival of Philippine films at the beginning of the 21st century.

 

Several films suffused with renewed nationalism came out during the centenaries of the Philippine revolution and independence from Spain. These films included Joey Romero’s Emilio Aguinaldo, 1998; Carlo J. Caparas’s Tirad Pass: The Last Stand of Gen. Gregorio del Pilar, 1996; and Jose Mari Avellana’s Damong Ligaw (Wild Grass), 1997, an adaptation of Ceres Alabado’s novel Kangkong 1896.

 

Jose Rizal was the subject of three films, two of which were mainstream, and one had a fiercely alternative take. Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s ambitious and lavish Jose Rizal, 1998, won most of the awards at the Metro Manila Film Festival. The film begins with Rizal’s childhood, delves into his fictional characters, and climaxes at his execution in Bagumbayan. Critics, however, point out historical inaccuracies and the movie’s failure to convincingly conjure the spirit of Rizal’s period (Dormiendo 2010). In contrast, Tikoy Aguiluz’s more modest Rizal sa Dapitan (Rizal in Dapitan), 1996, focuses on Rizal’s life as an exile in Dapitan, Zamboanga. Sisa , 1999, directed by Mario O’Hara, is a highly subjective take on the origins of Rizal’s fictional character. In Mike de Leon’s irreverent and witty Bayaning 3rd World , 1999, two filmmakers try to create a film about Jose Rizal and postulate provocative questions about nationhood, filmmaking, and heroism.

 

A near invincible hero who battles against powerful corrupt men typified the action films. Fernando Poe Jr led the pack of action stars, which included Robin Padilla, Jeric Raval, Phillip Salvador, Lito Lapid, Bong Revilla, Eddie Garcia, and Anthony Alonzo. Among the most notable traditional action films are Fernando Poe Jr’s Ang Probinsyano (The Country Boy), 1997, Robin Padilla’s Anak ni Baby Ama (Baby Ama’s Son), 1990, Phillip Salvador’s Boy Negro, 1988, Bong Revilla’s Sparrow Unit, 1987, and others. Since action was the highest-earning mainstream film, the genre’s decline in the succeeding years signaled the changing tastes and demographics of the Filipino audience.

 

Drama , regarded as the genre made for female audiences, overtook action movies near the end of the 1990s. Films in this genre explore personal relationships, family dynamics, the lives of overseas workers, class struggle between lovers, and the plight of the underprivileged. Among the leading performers were Lorna Tolentino, Maricel Soriano, Sharon Cuneta, and Judy Ann Santos. Most notable are the performances of Lorna Tolentino in Narito ang Puso Ko (Here Is My Heart), 1992, Maricel Soriano in Separada (Separated Woman), 1994, Sharon Cuneta in Madrasta (Stepmother), 1996, and Judy Ann Santos in Sabel, 2004. In Bata, Bata… Paano Ka Ginawa? (Lea’s Story), 1998, Leah Bustamante, played by Vilma Santos, raises her two children while working at a women’s crisis center. Adapted from Lualhati Bautista’s 1988 novel of the same title, Chito Roño’s film about a woman’s perspective and experiences in a chauvinistic society is considered one of the best of the decade. Another memorable drama is Rory Quintos’s Anak (The Child), 2000, which explores an overseas contract worker’s relationship with her daughter. Some other accomplished drama films are Joel Lamangan’s The Flor Contemplacion Story, 1995, which won the Golden Pyramid (Best Film) and the Princess Pataten Statue (Best Actress) for Nora Aunor at the 1995 Cairo International Film Festival; and Tikoy Aguiluz and Jose Lacaba’s Bagong Bayani (Unsung Heroine), 1995, which was lauded for the compassion and dignity with which it portrayed Contemplacion’s plight as an overseas worker.

 

Not too many bomba movies were produced in the first years of the 1990s, during which the genre was also called ST or “sex trip” film and TF or “titillating film” (Tolentino 2010, 106), but it grew in popularity later in the decade. Some of the most memorable traditional bomba films are Machete 2, 1994, starring Rosanna Roces; Scorpio Nights 2, 1999, starring Joyce Jimenez; Laro sa Baga (Playing with Fire), 2000, starring Ara Mina; and Sutla (Silk), 1999, starring Priscilla Almeda. A subversive take on the genre film is Jeffrey Jeturian’s Tuhog (Larger Than Life), 2000. A film within a film, Tuhog was hailed for its daring commentary, production values, and performances from Jaclyn Jose, Irma Adlawan, and Ina Raymundo.

 

Not surprisingly, the soft-porn films once again were at the center of disputes over censorship. The most divisive was Jose Javier Reyes’s Live Show (aka Toro), 2000, a film that reveals the dehumanizing conditions of sex workers. After a brief run, the film was pulled out from Philippine theaters. PresGloria Macapagal-Arroyo, pressured by Catholic groups, ordered the film’s permanent ban. Ironically, Live Show had been invited and exhibited at the Berlin Film Festival.

 

Perhaps the most successful fantasy and horror films of the decade are those directed by Peque Gallaga and Lore Reyes. Magic Temple, 1996, won Best Picture at the Metro Manila Film Festival. Magic Kingdom, 1997, the sequel, was also successful at the box office. Gallaga’s forays into the horror genre drew inspiration from his knowledge of Panayanon folklore. He directed some of the most memorable episodes of the Shake Rattle and Roll franchise, such as “Aswang” from the second film. The production cost of Gallaga’s Tiyanak (Changeling), 1986, may partly account for the dearth of horror films in the 1990s.

 

Comedy of the slapstick variety continued to be popular. Jimmy Santos, Andrew E., Michael V., and Rene Requiestas were new comedians that reveled in bawdy humor. Traditional examples of Pinoy comedy are Bondying, 1989, starring Jimmy Santos; Pido Dida, 1990, starring Rene Requiestas; Run Barbi Run, 1995, starring Joey de Leon; and Sinaktan Mo ang Puso Ko (You Hurt My Heart), 1998, starring Michael V. The comedian who went beyond cheap laughs was Jun Urbano, son of Manuel Conde, who created the shrewdly comical Mr Shooli. In Juan Tamad at Mister Shooli sa Mongolian Barbecue: The Movie, 1991, Urbano delivered comedy that also served as commentary on the ills of Philippine society (Tiongson 2010, 20).

 

Many of the directors who began to make a name in the 1970s and 1980s followed in the footsteps of their older contemporaries such as Lino Brocka and Ishmael Bernal by making New Cinema. Mario O’Hara, who won Best Director at the Gawad Urian in 1995 with the biopic The Fatima Buen Story, 1994, made the most with low-budget productions in the late 1990s. O’Hara eventually managed to show Babae sa Breakwater (Woman of Breakwater) at the Director’s Fortnight of the 2004 Cannes Film Festival. O’Hara also directed Babae sa Bubungang Lata (Woman on the Tin Roof), 1998, a surreal erotic film set in a Manila cemetery; and Pangarap ng Puso (Demons), 2000, based on a short story by Rosario Cruz-Lucero.

 

Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s Sa Pusod ng Dagat (In the Navel of the Sea), 1998, tells the story of a man who becomes the village midwife. Muro-ami (Reef Hunters), 1999, also directed by Diaz-Abaya, is about children who swim underwater for an abusive fisher-trader. Diaz-Abaya’s Bagong Buwan (New Moon), 2001, about ordinary people in Mindanao caught in a protracted conflict, was a rare and noteworthy undertaking. Incidentally, Visayan cinema momentarily found a champion in Cesar Montano, the star of Muro-Ami and Bagong Buwan.

 

In Butch Perez’s Mumbaki (Shaman), 1996, a medical doctor returns to his hometown in the Cordillera and reconciles himself with his family’s roots.

 

In 1998, Gil Portes directed Miguel/Michelle, in which a transsexual returns from the United States and shakes his family’s long-held beliefs. Portes adapted the life of Walter Dempster, a gay male sex slave during the Japanese occupation, in Markova: Comfort Gay, 2001.

 

Laurice Guillen’s Dahil Mahal Kita: The Dolzura Cortez Story (Because I Love You), 1993, is about the woman who became the first public face of HIV-AIDS in the Philippines.

 

Chito Roño’s Olongapo... The Great American Dream, 1987, depicted the lives of Filipinos in the US naval base. The film, according to one critic, foresees the pro-immigration policy of succeeding Philippine governments that later valorized the overseas workers as “new heroes” (Capino 2010, 90).

 

Jose Javier Reyes, considered to be one of the most prolific directors of the local movie scene, created memorable films like Makati Ave. (Office Girls), 1993, Batang PX (Phil-American Boy), 1993, and Live Show, 2000.

 

Carlos Siguion-Reyna is known for his radical emphasis on the female persona and her gender-related sensibilities, as shown in films like Inagaw Mo ang Lahat sa Akin (Harvest Home), 1995, Ang Lalaki sa Buhay ni Selya (The Man in Her Life), 1997, and Ligaya ang Itawag Mo sa Akin (They Call Me Joy), 1997.

 

Midway into the 2000s, the introduction of digital video technology inspired the emergence of independent films and saw Philippine cinema at a turning point. The era of the Philippine New Wave independent films began and marshaled a group of young filmmakers who were trained in film schools, received grants from the Cinemalaya Foundation and Cinema One Originals among others, and had set their eyes on local and international film festival circuits (Tiongson 2013, 4-16). These new film-educated directors, screenwriters, cinematographers, and producers, like the alternative filmmakers before them, spurned the commercialism of a declining industry to pursue their respective artistic visions. Not only did new grant-giving institutions begin to support young filmmakers, they also helped in forming an educated middle-class audience that patronized digital independent film festivals (Tiongson 2013, 6).

 

Digital video cameras that were significantly more affordable and easier to handle than film cameras appeared in the market, thus democratizing filmmaking for young students of film. Jon Red’s Still Lives, 1999, a film about a drug syndicate, is considered the first full-length digital film to be produced in the Philippines (Hernandez 2014a, 23). Also shot on digital video cameras are other pioneering independent films like Motel, 1999, a compendium of three short films by Nonoy Dadivas, Chuck Escasa, and Ed Lejano, which focuses on three different lovers who go to the same motel on Valentine’s Day, and The Twelve, 2000, directed by Khavn dela Cruz, a contemporary representation of Jesus’s apostles. Independent filmmakers found creative means to go about marketing and distribution. Crisaldo Pablo’s Duda (Doubt), 2003, is the first digital film projected in a commercial theater when it was shown in SM cinemas. Pablo himself sought the digital film projector for the screenings. It did not take long before commercial cinemas, such as Robinsons Galleria and SM cinemas, acquired digital projectors of their own (Tiongson 2013, 16).

 

The Cinemalaya Philippine Independent Film Festival was successfully launched in July 2005, with nine features receiving 500,000 pesos seed fund. Clodualdo del Mundo Jr’s Pepot Artista (Pepot Superstar), a comedy musical about a boy who dreams of becoming a movie actor in the 1970s, won best film. Succeeding Best Film winners are Mike Sandeja’s Tulad ng Dati (Just Like Before), 2006, about the early years of the rock band The Dawn; Jim Libiran’s Tribu (Tribe), 2007, about gang culture in Tondo; Chris Martinez’s 100, 2008, about a dying woman’s journey to accomplish her goals; and Veronica B. Velasco’s Last Supper No. 3, 2009, which follows a production designer as he tries to clear his name when a prop he borrowed is stolen. Other films that received recognition from the Cinemalaya include Sheron Dayoc’s Halaw (Ways of the Sea), 2010, about human trafficking that occurs between ports in Mindanao and Sabah; Marlon Rivera’s Ang Babae sa Septic Tank (The Woman in the Septic Tank), 2011, a comedy that satirizes independent films about poverty; Mes de Guzman’s Diablo (The Devil), 2012, about a woman haunted at night by a sinister figure; Hannah Espia’s Transit, 2013, about an overseas worker in Israel who hides her children from immigration officers; and Francis Xavier Pasion’s Bwaya (Crocodile), 2014, about a woman whose daughter is attacked by a crocodile in the Agusan marshland.

 

Established in 2005, Cinema One Originals Film Festival showcased six digital independent films in its first festival. The number of entries has since expanded to nine or more. Notable films include Dennis Marasigan’s Sa North Diversion Road (On the North Diversion Road), 2005, an adaptation of a play by Tony Perez; Sherad Anthony Sanchez’s Huling Balyan ng Buhi (TheW oven Stories of the Other), 2006, a confounding intersection of tales about identity, loss, and change set in war-torn Mindanao; Jerrold Tarog and Ruel Dahis Antipuesto’s Confessional, 2007, about a politician who admits to his crimes on camera; Imburnal (Sewer), 2008, also by Sherad Anthony Sanchez, a slow, three-and-a-half-hour film about two boys in the midst of violence and poverty in Mindanao; Ray Dante Gibraltar’s Wanted: Border, 2009, about a landlady rumored to be an aswang; Michael Angelo Dagñalan’s Layang Bilanggo (Imprisoned Freedom), 2010, about an aging assassin on the run; Sari Dalena’s Ka Oryang, 2011, about a woman activist involved in the underground movement during the Marcos regime; Pam Miras’s Pascalina, 2012, about a young woman who transforms after the death of a relative; Jet Leyco’s Bukas Na Lang Sapagkat Gabi Na (Leave It for Tomorrow, for Night Has Fallen), 2013, about four interlinked stories concerning the war between the military and the insurgents; Eduardo Dayao’s Violator, 2014, about people in a Manila police precinct during a typhoon; and Carl Joseph Papa’s Manang Biring, an animated film about an old woman stricken with stage-four cancer.

 

Digital Lokal, a section of the Cinemanila International Film Festival, awarded remarkable films such as Auraeus Solito’s Tuli (Circumcision), 2005; Brillante Mendoza’s Manoro (The Teacher), 2006; Raya Martin’s Autohystoria, 2007; Sherad Anthony Sanchez’s Imburnal; Christopher Gozum’s Anacbanua (The Child of the Sun), 2009; Ato Bautista’s ’Di Natatapos ang Gabi (Night Doesn’t End), 2010; Mes de Guzman’s Sa Kanto ng Ulap at Lupa (Of Skies and Earth ), 2011; Gutierrez Mangansakan II’s Obscured Histories and Silent Longings of Daguluan’s Children, 2012; and Raya Martin’s How to Disappear Completely, 2013.

 

Other film festivals that supported the digital independent films included the Filipino Full-Length Feature Indie Festival, also known as the CCP Freefest, and Filmless Films’ Digital Film Fest. By 2005, support for independent films, both from government and private foundations, reached an unprecedented scale. There were also some independent filmmakers who successfully produced films outside of the model provided by grant-giving institutions.

 

Major indie film directors produced a number of films with varying styles. Raya Martin, aside from getting grants abroad, collaborated with another filmmaker to produce his films. With Arlene Cuevas, he produced his first movies under Cinematografica (Hernandez 2014b, 176)—namely, Maicling Pelicula nañg Ysañg Indio Nacional (A Short Film about the Indio Nacional), 2005, Now Showing, 2008, Next Attraction, 2008, and Independencia (Independence), 2009. An entry in the Un Certain Regard section of the 2009 Cannes Film Festival, Independencia is set during the early years of the American occupation and tells the story of a family displaced by the invasion. Martin stylistically mimics the period the film evokes by shooting in black and white and using sets resembling those from early American studio photography (Tiongson 2013, 21).

 

John Torres ingeniously wove found footage from personal trips, illustrations, text messages, and concert clips to create Todo Todo Teros, 2005. Instead of a script, Torres began with found footage and assembled his film from there (Hernandez 2014b, 158). The result is a deeply personal film about a married man who begins a love affair with a Russian woman. Torres used a similar collage-like method with Taon Noong Ako’y Anak sa Labas (Years When I Was a Child Outside), 2008. He incorporated video recording of his house after a typhoon, various found footage, and an interview with Jose Maria Sison of the Communist Party of the Philippines to create a film about reckoning with his father’s admission that he has another family (Hernandez 2014b, 165).

 

Two of the independent Filipino filmmakers who have won various awards in major international film festivals are Lav Diaz and Brillante Mendoza. Batang West Side (West Side Kid), 2001, Lav Diaz’s five-hour film about the death of a Filipino teen in New Jersey, signaled his shift to a more audacious and uncompromising cinema. The following year, Diaz released Hesus, Rebolusyunaryo (Hesus the Revolutionary), a political drama set in the future. This was followed by Ebolusyon ng Isang Pamilyang Pilipino (Evolution of a Filipino Family), 2004, a 10-hour epic that condenses the nation’s history in a saga about a peasant family. Diaz is known for his social epics characterized by long takes, black-and-white cinematography, and running time of 5 to 10hours. In Kagadanansa Banwa an ning mga Engkanto (Death in the Land of Encantos), 2007, a poet returns to his typhoon-ravaged hometown. Norte, Hangganan ng Kasaysayan (Norte, The End of History), 2013, follows the moral descent of a law school dropout. Mula sa Kung Ano ang Noon (From What Is Before), 2014, describes the events in a remote village days before Ferdinand Marcos declares martial law.

 

Many of Brillante Mendoza’s films convey a society gripped by a sense of dread and desperation. Mendoza collaborated with writer Armando Lao to produce some of the most emblematic films of the period. Serbis (Service), 2008, portrays a family in Angeles, Pampanga, living inside a decaying theater that shows soft-core pornography and serves as a venue for prostitution among its male clients. Kinatay (The Execution of P.), 2009, for which Mendoza won Best Director at the Cannes Film Festival, follows a criminology student who is pulled into a drug syndicate’s underworld where he witnesses the abduction, rape, and brutal murder of a prostitute. Tirador (Slingshot), 2007, written by Ralston Jover, presents a grim picture of a shantytown in Quiapo as symptomatic of a larger problem—the corruption of people in power. Mendoza shifts his focus on a Sama Dilaut midwife searching for a woman who will bear her husband’s child in Thy Womb, 2012. Taklub (Trap), 2015, describes the lives of people in Tacloban after Typhoon Haiyan devastated the city in November 2013.

 

Jun Lana’s Bwakaw, 2012, is about an elderly gay man who falls in love with a tricycle driver. His other memorable films are Barber’s Tales, 2013, and Anino sa Likod ng Buwan (Shadow behind the Moon), 2015.

 

Digital filmmaking decentralized film production, which used to be controlled by a small number of studios (Tiongson 2013, 29). Thus, regional cinema flourished during the New Wave of Philippine independent films. The National Commission for Culture and the Arts established film festivals showing independent films from Baguio, Naga, Cebu, Iloilo, Davao, and Cagayan de Oro (Tiongson 2013, 16). In Cebu, a group led by experimental filmmaker Keith Deligero launched the Binisaya Film Festival. In Davao City, the Mindanao Film Festival has been holding a short film competition since 2004. In General Santos City, SalaMindanaw Asian Film Festival showcases films from Mindanao and Asia.

 

In Mes de Guzman’s Ang Daan Patungong Kalimugtong (The Road to Kalimugtong), 2005, two young Benguet children walk a long, perilous road to school every day. De Guzman is also known for films like The Earth Trilogy, 2010-13, and Ang Kuwento ni Mabuti (The Story of Mabuti), 2013. Gozum’s Anacbanua, considered the first Pangasinense-language film, is about a man who returns from the Middle East to his hometown in Pangasinan. In Brillante Mendoza’s Manoro, a young Aeta teaches her elders how to read and write so they could participate in the presidential elections. Jason Paul Laxamana’s Astro Mayabang (Proud Astro), 2010, tells the story of a proud young man in Pampanga who befriends a Filipino-American girl, while his Ang Magkakabaung (The Coffin Maker), 2014, revolves around the Pampango characters who are buried in their poverty and past relationships.

 

Other memorable directors are Alvin Yapan, who hails from Bicol and is well-known for films like Gayuma (Pilgrim Lovers), 2011, and Debosyon (Devotion), 2013. Yapan’s Ang Sayaw ng Dalawang Kaliwang Paa (The Dance of Two Left Feet), 2011, is about two male college students who discover the intricacies of desire through poetry and dance. Artikulo Uno’s Antonio Luna biopic Heneral Luna (General Luna), 2015, directed by Jerrold Tarog, straddles both independent and mainstream cinemas. The film’s reported budget of 80 million pesos is unusual for an independent film, but word-of-mouth on social media platforms helped to extend its screenings for more than five weeks, resulting in unprecedented box-office returns (San Diego 2015). In Ivan Zaldarriaga’s Dili Ingon ’Nato (Not Like Us), 2011, a Cebuano town is attacked by reanimated, flesh-eating corpses. My Paranormal Romance, 2011, directed by Victor Villanueva, is a Cebuano comedy romance. Keith Deligero’s Iskawalags, 2013, is about a group of young boys who reenact scenes from their favorite Tagalog action films in a fictional Cebuano town.

 

Richard Somes, who hails from Negros Occidental, directed Yanggaw (Affliction ), 2008, a horror film about a young woman who, according to local belief, is afflicted with an illness that will turn her into a monster. Another notable film by Somes is Corazon: Ang Unang Aswang (Corazon: The First Aswang), 2012.

 

From Iloilo is director Lawrence Fajardo, recognized in the film community through his works such as Kultado (Boiling Point), 2005, Amok, 2011, Posas (Shackled), 2012, and Imbisibol (Invisible), 2015.

 

In Mindanao, Davao City’s Sherad Anthony Sanchez directed Huling Balyan ng Buhi, about a balyan (shaman) in the Arakan Valley, and Imburnal, about delinquent teenagers in Davao City.

 

Arnel Mardoquio wrote and directed Hunghong sa Yuta (Earth’s Whisper), 2008, Sheika, 2010, Ang Paglalakay ng mga Bituin sa Gabing Madilim (The Journey of Stars into the Dark Night), 2012, and Ang Tigmo sa Aking Pagpauli (Riddles of My Homecoming), 2013—all films confronting contemporary issues in Mindanao. Gutierrez Mangansakan II, a Maguindanaon, has directed prizewinning films that probe into the Filipino Muslim psyche. Mangansakan’s films include Limbunan (The Bridal Quarter), 2010, about a young girl’s coming-of-age, and Qiyamah (The Reckoning), 2012, which chronicles events in a Maguindanaon village leading to the apocalypse.

 

Auraeus Solito, who hails from Palawan, is well-known for films like Busong (Palawan Fate), 2011, and Baybayin (The Palawan Script), 2012.

 

There are also independent filmmakers involved in political film collectives, such as Sine Patriyotiko, Kodao Productions, Tudlao Productions, and Southern Tagalog Exposure. These filmmakers make documentaries that help organize communities toward political transformation and, therefore, in pursuit of a much more emancipatory function of film (Tolentino 2013, 65).

 

Since media conglomerates are beginning to distribute a number of independent films, like Marlon Rivera’s comedy Ang Babae sa Septic Tank and Antoinette Jadaone’s romance That Thing Called Tadhana (That Thing Called Fate), 2014, some filmmakers seek the balance between artistic integrity and marketability. Major media conglomerates, such as ABS-CBN’s Star Cinema, cannot ignore the digital independent film phenomenon. In 2013, Star Cinema partnered with Reality Entertainment to produce Erik Matti’s On the Job, a crime thriller that combines the polish of mainstream cinema and the grit of independent films.

 

Conclusion

 

After the 1986 EDSA Revolt, Philippine cinema experienced a period of decline that reflected the nation’s struggle to restore democracy. The deficiency both in quality and revenue of mainstream cinema in the 1990s signaled the industry’s defeat by big-budget global films. A new breed of independent filmmakers rose and seized digital video technology to create audacious, uncompromising, and innovative cinema. Because of its affordability and versatility, independent filmmakers found more freedom with the digital video format. Grant-giving institutions and film festivals sustain the development of independent filmmaking and continue to discover new talents. Independent cinema from the regions reveals various facets of experience rarely seen in mainstream films. Although much still needs to be done, especially in the areas of promotion and distribution of films, the gap between digital independent films and the Filipino audience is starting to shrink. Thus, the future of Philippine film no longer forecasts gloomy conditions but a vast and rich cinematic landscape.    Written by John Bengan, with notes from Johann Vladimir J. Espiritu  and Nicanor G. Tiongson
